Exercise

A matrix is called symmetric if is it symmetric across the main diagonal. In other words, transposing these matrices, i.e. interchanging their rows and columns, does not change them: \[A^T=A.\]

Select exactly the symmetric matrices:

[[input:ans_sym_list]] [[validation:ans_sym_list]] [[feedback:prt_sym_list]]

generalfeedback.text:
Let \(A = {@a1@}\). Then \(A^T = {@a1@} = A\), therefore \(A\) is symmetric.

Let \(A = {@a2@}\). Then \(A^T = {@transpose(a2)@} \neq A\), therefore \(A\) is not symmetric.

Let \(A = {@a3@}\). Then \(A^T = {@transpose(a3)@} = A\), therefore \(A\) is symmetric.

Let \(A = {@a4@}\). Then \(A^T = {@transpose(a4)@} \neq A\), therefore \(A\) is not symmetric.

Let \(A = {@a5@}\). Then \(A^T = {@transpose(a5)@} = A\), therefore \(A\) is symmetric.

Let \(A = {@a6@}\). Then \(A^T = {@transpose(a6)@} \neq A\), therefore \(A\) is not symmetric.
